awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Investigating Fifth Grade Teachers' Knowledge of Noticing Appalachian Students' Thinking in Science
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a Faculty Early Career Development Program (CAREER) proposal responsive to Program Solicitation NSF 15-555. The CAREER program is a National Science Foundation-wide activity that offers the most prestigious awards in support of junior faculty who exemplify the role of teacher-scholars through outstanding research, excellent education and the integration of education and research. Based on findings from research on effective science teaching supporting the notion that meaningful learning occurs when teachers attend to students' thinking, this project will conduct an in-depth investigation of teachers' knowledge of noticing students' science thinking in terms of what they do and say, to not only attend to their ideas, but also to make sense of and respond to those ideas. The work will be grounded on the premise that there is a relationship between teachers' practice and knowledge, and that it is possible to observe practice in order to infer knowledge. The project will examine teacher noticing in practice, use empirical evidence to model the specialized teacher knowledge involved, and design teacher learning materials informed by the model. The setting of the study will include an existing school-university partnership serving diverse student populations in Appalachian communities, where students significantly underperform nationally in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics areas across grades levels. It will target fifth grade science teachers' noticing their students' thinking as they engage in science learning in six rural and semi-rural elementary schools.

The three research questions will be: (1) What disciplinary ideas in students' thinking do elementary teachers notice in practice?; (2) What knowledge do elementary teachers draw on when noticing the disciplinary ideas in students' thinking in practice?; and (3) How does a set of web-based interactive instructional materials support teachers' knowledge construction around noticing the disciplinary ideas in students' thinking in science? In order to investigate teachers' noticing students' thinking, and answer the research questions, the project will use two wearable technologies to collect data of teachers' "in-the-moment" noticing while engaged in planning, instructional, and assessment  activities. One is a point-of-view digital video system consisting of three parts: a small video camera, a hand-held remote, and a separate recording module. The other is an audio-recording wristband with a recording mode allowing the user to capture previous one-minute loops of audio data. An audio loop is saved whenever the user taps the wristband. Data will be analyzed for evidence of students' disciplinary knowledge and skills in order to give insight of teachers' knowledge involved in noticing each instance using the three interconnected dimensions featured in "A Framework for K-12 Science Education" (National Research Council, 2012). The project will consist of four strands of work: (1) empirically investigating teachers' noticing of students' thinking; (2) developing an initial conceptual model of teachers' knowledge of noticing students' thinking; (3) conducting design-based research to develop instructional materials supporting teachers' knowledge construction around noticing students' thinking in science; and (4) producing and disseminating these instructional materials through an interactive web-based platform. The main outcomes of this project will be (a) an empirically grounded model of fifth grade teachers' knowledge of noticing Appalachian students' thinking in science; and (b) the design of web-based interactive instructional materials supporting fifth grade teachers' knowledge construction around noticing Appalachian students' thinking in science. These outcomes will serve as the foundation for a more comprehensive future research agenda testing and refining the initial model and instructional materials in other learning environments in order to eventually contribute to a practice-based theory of teachers' knowledge of noticing students' thinking in science to inform and impact science teaching practice. An advisory board will oversee the project's progress, and an external evaluator will conduct both formative and summative evaluation.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project was to investigate and support 5th grade teachers' Knowledge of Noticing Appalachian students' thinking in science to inform and impact science teaching practice.

DESIGN OUTCOME:

a online teacher learning platform--the Knowledge of Noticing Project (i.e. the KON Project)

Project Website: https://knowledgeofnoticing.org/

The project website supports the KON Project PD which is focused on supporting WV fifth grade teachers in building their Teacher Noticing practice across the work of teaching science--in planning lessons, in teaching, and in assessing student understanding. The focus is on both WHAT to teach (WV Science Standards) and HOW to teach science (approach). The KON Project PD involves a web-based, highly interactive, collaborative professional learning community that is: (1) sustained and ongoing, (2) flexible, and (3) practiced-based.

The PD design involves a series of eight teacher learning sessions focused on building skills around the practice of noticing students' thinking and the implementation of the NGSS. The series involves both asynchronous and synchronous teacher learning activities. Each session is designed to occur over a 2-week period. The provided link brings visitors to the home page where an overview of the KON Project is provided and where visitors can request more information.

KEY RESEARCH FINDINGS:

  • Findings support that there exists a special kind of teacher knowledge--a Knowledge of Noticing--unique to the practice of Teacher Noticing that teachers draw on while engaged in the work of teaching science. Project data suggests teachers primarily drew on four types of knowledge as they actively noticed their students' thinking: knowledge of disciplinary content and practices, knowledge of Appalachia (i.e. place), knowledge of science teaching, and knowledge of students. Interestingly, teachers' moment-to-moment noticing almost always involved a combination of at least 2, usually 3, and sometimes all 4 types of knowledge. This suggests that Knowledge of Noticing involves a mix of different types of knowledge at play while teachers are actively noticing their students' thinking.
  • Elementary teachers who participated in the KON Project in some way (either by engaging in the KON Project PD or by participating as a research subject in the empirical study that served as the basis for the design of the PD) demonstrated growth in their understanding and enactment of noticing students' disciplinary thinking in science. This suggests that overall, the KON Project focus and the interactive web-based PD model can support elementary teachers' learning to notice the disciplinary substance in their students' thinking across the work of teaching science.
  • Aspects of the Appalachian context were consistently present in teachers' noticing of students' thinking during science. This suggests that Teacher Noticing in an Appalachian context draws on teachers' context specific knowledge of place and community. This raises the question of whether teachers in other different contexts also draw on context specific knowledge of place and community, and, if they do, to what extent? Relatedly, do teachers in Appalachia have a unique set of knowledge they draw on when noticing students' thinking? How does this impact science teaching practice and students' learning in Appalachian contexts? Findings from this project suggest there is something unique about Appalachian teachers' Knowledge of Noticing, but comparison studies have not yet been conducted (this is for future work).

DISSEMINATION ACTIVITY:

KON Project findings and outcomes were disseminated to STEM education stakeholders:

  • Research community: 9 journal publications, 1 book chapter, 4 published proceedings, and 22 conference presentations.
  • Practitioner community: 3 conference presentations, 15 professional development sessions, and 5 virtual outreach events focused on introducing the KON project to teachers, instructional coaches, and school leaders.
  • Policy makers: one visit to Capitol Hill and a featured exhibit at the Coalition for National Science Funding (CNSF) 24th Annual Exhibition (2018) to share the project and STEM education research with WV representatives and senators specifically and other members of congress and their staff more broadly.
  • STEM education stakeholders could access project related information, products, and outcomes through a project profile maintained on the Community for Advancing Discovery Research in Education (CADRE) platform.

IMPACT:

Intellectual Merit. Building from prior research on teacher knowledge, this project contributes to a practice-based theory of teachers' Knowledge of Noticing at play when actively attending to, making sense of, and responding to students' thinking in science and engineering.

Broader Impacts. Participating teachers report that actively noticing and discussing their students' thinking in science through their participation in this project supported their learning to teach science in reform-oriented ways. Participating teachers and their students reside in Appalachian communities serving low-income populations typically underrepresented in STEM fields. Thus, by impacting teachers' science teaching practice, the KON Project has broadened participation in STEM learning among low SES Appalachian children. Also, over its duration, the KON project provided research opportunities and mentorship for five graduate students in STEM Education and Human Services fields.
